memories.content: Calendar aggregator project initial state: This is a modern Next.js 15 webapp with TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and shadcn/ui components. It's designed for a beginner developer to learn modern web development. Has proper dev environment setup with testing (Vitest), linting (ESLint), formatting (Prettier), and git hooks (Husky). Core UI components are already implemented (buttons, inputs, cards, dialogs, etc.). Project structure follows Next.js App Router pattern.
memories.context: Initial project exploration

memories.content: Calendar aggregator project successfully initialized with Next.js 15, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, and shadcn/ui. All tests pass (9/9), linting clean, type checking successful. Git repository initialized with initial commit. Development environment ready. Security middleware configured with CSP headers. Ready for calendar aggregation features to be built.
memories.context: Project initialization completion

memories.content:
User wants to ideate an application that will:
1. Stand up an API
2. Combine several calendar feeds (e.g., iCal)
3. Output one unified calendar feed (e.g., iCal)

Currently in plan mode - need to research codebase first, then present comprehensive plan.
memories.context: Starting calendar aggregator ideation task

memories.content:
Research findings from agent:
- Next.js 15 with TypeScript, App Router
- Tailwind CSS with shadcn/ui components
- Vitest testing configured
- Clean slate - no existing calendar code or API routes
- Node.js 18.17.0+, React 19, strict TypeScript
- Git repo initialized with one commit

Key insight: This is a fresh project ready for implementing calendar aggregation features from scratch.
memories.context: Codebase research complete for calendar aggregator

memories.content:
Successfully created comprehensive implementation plan document at /docs/IMPLEMENTATION_PLAN.md. Plan covers 6 phases over 14 days:
1. Core Infrastructure (2 days)
2. Calendar Management (2 days) 
3. Event Aggregation Engine (3 days)
4. API Endpoints (2 days)
5. Frontend Interface (3 days)
6. Testing & Polish (2 days)

Quality hook approved the documentation. Ready to proceed with implementation starting with Phase 1.
memories.context: Implementation plan documentation complete

memories.content: User clarified that Claude commands should be plain English instructions for LLM, not bash scripts. I incorrectly created a bash script instead of a Claude Code command file with natural language instructions.
memories.context: Claude Code command creation - need to fix approach

memories.content: Starting safe implementation of calendar aggregator project. Plan shows 6 phases: 1) Core Infrastructure (2 days), 2) Calendar Management (2 days), 3) Event Aggregation Engine (3 days), 4) API Endpoints (2 days), 5) Frontend Interface (3 days), 6) Testing & Polish (2 days). Beginning with Phase 1 - Core Infrastructure setup.
memories.context: Safe implementation workflow started

memories.content: Research complete: Calendar dependencies already installed (node-ical 0.20.1, axios 1.11.0, date-fns 4.1.0). No existing API routes. Next.js app directory structure is basic with only layout.tsx and page.tsx. TypeScript types for node-ical will need to be added.
memories.context: Phase 1 research findings

memories.content: Phase 1 Core Infrastructure completed successfully! Created complete API structure with calendars CRUD, events endpoint, sync endpoint, and health check. All TypeScript interfaces defined with proper typing. Build verification passed with 0 errors. Project now has solid foundation for calendar aggregation functionality.
memories.context: Phase 1 completion milestone

memories.content: Starting Phase 2: Calendar Management. Objectives: URL validation and testing, calendar source management, basic fetching infrastructure. Will implement calendar validation, connection testing, and error handling for network failures.
memories.context: Phase 2 implementation starting

memories.content: Research findings: Existing utils.ts has basic utility functions (clsx, date formatting, sleep, capitalize). Axios is available as dependency. Need to create calendar-specific validation utilities including URL validation, iCal format validation, and network connection testing.
memories.context: Phase 2 research findings

memories.content: Phase 2 Calendar Management completed successfully! Implemented comprehensive URL validation, calendar connection testing, fetching infrastructure, and enhanced sync operations. All build errors resolved, TypeScript strict compliance maintained. Ready for Phase 3: Event Aggregation Engine.
memories.context: Phase 2 completion milestone

memories.content: README.md successfully updated with comprehensive user instructions for the calendar aggregator API. Added complete API documentation with examples, supported calendar formats, technology stack info, project structure, testing instructions, current limitations, and deployment guide. Removed all Ken's generic webapp content and replaced with calendar-specific documentation.
memories.context: README update completion - user requested comprehensive user instructions

memories.content:
Calendar aggregator API testing completed successfully! Both test URLs from .env.local (Google Calendar and Outlook) work perfectly. Fixed storage inconsistency issue between calendar routes and sync route. 

Test results:
- Google Calendar: 1,455 events processed successfully
- Outlook Calendar: 90 events processed successfully  
- Total: 1,545 events synced
- URL validation works (rejects invalid domains)
- Duplicate prevention works correctly
- Sync status tracking functions properly
- All API endpoints responding correctly
memories.context: Comprehensive API testing with real calendar URLs

memories.content:
OpenAPI specification document created successfully for Calendar Aggregator API. Comprehensive documentation includes all endpoints, schemas, examples, and error responses. 

Current test results show:
- Calendar management working perfectly (creation, validation, sync status)
- Sync operation processes events correctly (1,545 events from Google + Outlook calendars)
- Events endpoint currently returns placeholder data (Phase 3 implementation needed)

The API is in Phase 2 state - calendar management and syncing works, but event storage/retrieval is not yet implemented. Sync operation fetches and counts events but doesn't persist them for later retrieval.
memories.context: OpenAPI documentation completion and current API state assessment

memories.content: Successfully created comprehensive GUID-based workflow plan document at docs/GUID_WORKFLOW_PLAN.md. Plan shows minimal refactoring needed (9 hours vs 20+ hours for event persistence). Key insight: 85% of existing code can be reused, especially the proven calendar fetching infrastructure that already processes 1,545 events successfully. New approach eliminates complexity of event storage/sync and provides real-time calendar aggregation via simple GUID-based requests.
memories.context: GUID workflow plan documentation completion

memories.content: Starting safe implementation of GUID-based workflow for calendar aggregator. Plan written to docs/GUID_WORKFLOW_PLAN.md shows 85% code reuse possible. Need to implement: 1) Calendar collections data model 2) GUID-based API endpoint 3) Real-time calendar fetching 4) Response aggregation
memories.context: Beginning implementation of Phase 3 GUID workflow from detailed plan

memories.content: Created implementation plan with 6 tasks. Found existing codebase patterns - CalendarSource interface, fetchMultipleCalendars function (proven to work with 1,545 events), axios HTTP fetching, iCal parsing with node-ical. Will reuse 85% of existing code. Key files: src/types/calendar.ts (existing types), src/lib/calendar-fetcher.ts (proven fetching)
memories.context: Completed research phase, starting Task 1: Create calendar collections data model

memories.content: Task 1 completed: Added CalendarCollection, CombineResult, CreateCollectionRequest, UpdateCollectionRequest interfaces to src/types/calendar.ts. Data model reuses existing CalendarSource interface as planned. Quality hook passed.
memories.context: Moving to Task 2: Build GUID management API

memories.content: Task 2 completed: Created GUID management API with full CRUD operations. Created /api/collections route with GET/POST for listing and creating collections, and /api/collections/[guid] route with GET/PUT/DELETE for individual collection management. Follows existing patterns from calendars API, includes URL validation, duplicate checking, error handling. Quality hooks passed.
memories.context: Moving to Task 3: Create iCal combiner utility

memories.content: Task 3 completed: Created comprehensive iCal combiner utility with two implementations - raw iCal combining (preserves original formatting, timezones, handles deduplication) and parsed events fallback. Includes proper iCal structure with headers/footers, timezone extraction, event deduplication by UID, error handling and warnings. Quality hook passed.
memories.context: Moving to Task 4: Implement main GUID endpoint

memories.content: Task 4 completed: Implemented main GUID endpoint at /api/calendar/[guid] with GET and HEAD methods. Features: GUID validation, collection lookup, real-time calendar fetching with configurable timeout, partial success handling (206 status), proper iCal content-type headers, caching headers, detailed metadata headers. Quality hook passed.
memories.context: Moving to Task 6: Build verification (skipping OpenAPI update for now to ensure build works)

memories.content: Build verification successful! All 4 core tasks completed: 1) Data model with CalendarCollection interfaces 2) GUID management API with full CRUD operations 3) iCal combiner utility with raw feed merging and deduplication 4) Main GUID endpoint for real-time calendar aggregation. TypeScript compilation successful, all new API routes built properly.
memories.context: Ready to commit the working GUID-based workflow implementation

memories.content: Updating OpenAPI specification to reflect GUID-based collection endpoints. The current openapi.yaml contains the old ID-based calendar management system, but the implementation now uses GUID-based collections with endpoints like /api/collections and /api/calendar/[guid]. Need to replace the old endpoints with the new collection-based API structure.

User requests: 1) Update README with new GUID-based workflow, 2) Create styled frontpage with instructions and examples, include attribution to "Created by balddata.xyz (sean@balddata.xyz)". Need to document the successful GUID-based implementation that's currently deployed and working.

Successfully completed both user requests: 1) Updated README.md with comprehensive GUID-based workflow documentation including live demo URL, quick start guide, and new API endpoints. 2) Created a beautiful styled frontpage (src/app/page.tsx) with full instructions, examples, feature highlights, and attribution to balddata.xyz (sean@balddata.xyz). The frontpage includes working example with the deployed GUID, interactive copy buttons, and step-by-step guide for creating and subscribing to calendar collections.

From the continued session summary: The user's calendar aggregator is fully implemented and deployed. They had two final issues: 1) "View API" button pointing to non-existent /api route (should point to /api/health) 2) Need detailed POST parameters documentation for /api/collections endpoint. Both issues appear to be already resolved in the current page.tsx file which shows the button pointing to /api/health and comprehensive "How to Create a Collection" section with detailed parameter documentation. The todos show all tasks completed. The user's last two requests have been successfully addressed.
memories.context: Session continuation from calendar aggregator work - final fixes to frontpage

memories.content: Fixed Vercel build error: TypeScript couldn't find '@/types/calendar' module in calendar/[guid]/route.ts. Added missing global type declaration to match pattern used in collections/route.ts. Local build now passes successfully. Committed and pushed fix to trigger new Vercel deployment. The issue was that the GUID route file was missing the global storage type declaration for calendarCollections.
memories.context: Vercel build failure fix

memories.content: Fixed persistent Vercel build issue by switching from path aliases (@/types/calendar) to relative imports (../../../../types/calendar) in the calendar GUID route. The path aliases work locally but Vercel's build environment had module resolution issues. Also updated the frontpage example to show complete response structure with both calendars (Google Calendar and Outlook Calendar) including all fields like id, name, url, color, enabled, and syncStatus. This better demonstrates the calendar aggregation concept with 2 calendars as requested.
memories.context: Vercel build fix and frontpage example improvement

memories.content: Successfully resolved Vercel build failure by systematically converting all critical API routes and lib files from path aliases (@/) to relative imports. Key fixes: 1) All API routes (calendars, collections, sync) 2) All lib files (calendar-fetcher, ical-combiner) 3) Updated frontpage example to show complete response with 2 calendars. Build now passes locally and deployed to Vercel. The issue was that Vercel's build environment couldn't resolve the tsconfig path aliases, while they worked fine locally. Relative imports work in both environments.
memories.context: Vercel build resolution - systematic path alias to relative import conversion

memories.content: User is testing the API with a real collection of 5 calendars: Default (Google), Sean (Google group), CGD (Outlook Office365), SMEC (Outlook Office365), and South East Leisure (PerfectGym). Getting "URL and name are required" error despite all entries having both fields. Need to debug the validation logic in collections API.
memories.context: API testing with real calendar URLs

memories.content: Starting safe implementation of Supabase backend for calendar aggregator. Goal: Make calendar GUIDs persistent across server restarts with simplest possible implementation.
memories.context: Beginning comprehensive implementation following safe development practices

memories.content: Discovered current architecture: Uses globalThis.calendarCollections for in-memory storage. CalendarCollection interface at src/types/calendar.ts:110-117 has guid, name, description, calendars (CalendarSource[]), createdAt, updatedAt. Two main API routes handle collections: /api/collections (POST) and /api/collections/[guid] (GET/PUT/DELETE).
memories.context: Codebase analysis for Supabase integration

memories.content: Task 1 completed: Created schema.sql with calendar_collections table (guid UUID PK, name TEXT, description TEXT, sources JSONB, timestamps). Added StoredCalendarCollection interface extending CalendarCollection with database-specific fields. Schema includes indexes for performance and RLS enabled for future auth.
memories.context: Task 1 implementation - database schema

memories.content: Task 2 completed: Installed @supabase/supabase-js, created src/lib/supabase.ts with lazy-loaded client, updated .env.example with Supabase vars, enhanced health endpoint with Supabase status checking. Build passes successfully. Supabase client uses lazy initialization to avoid build-time errors when env vars missing.
memories.context: Task 2 implementation - Supabase client configuration

memories.content: Task 3 completed: Successfully integrated Supabase into API routes. Updated /api/collections (GET/POST) and /api/collections/[guid] (GET/PUT/DELETE) to use Supabase with graceful fallback to in-memory storage. Added database helper functions for CRUD operations. Build passes successfully with all linting issues resolved.
memories.context: Task 3 implementation - API routes with Supabase integration

memories.content: Found existing CLAUDE.md file that is comprehensive and well-structured. It contains detailed architecture documentation, development commands, and project-specific patterns. The file is already properly formatted and covers all the key areas: development workflow, technology stack, architecture patterns, data flow, implementation details, testing strategy, and common development tasks.

Starting dead code analysis for calendar-aggregator project. Need to analyze TypeScript/JavaScript files in src/ directory for unused imports, functions, components, variables, and commented code blocks.

Dead code analysis findings:
1. UI Components (all unused): Button, Card, Dialog, Input, Select, Toast, Loading, Error Boundary - none imported/used in app
2. Hooks (unused): useDebounce, useLocalStorage - both exported but never used
3. Utility functions: formatDate, sleep, capitalize from utils.ts - only used in tests, not in production code
4. Empty directories: repositories/ and services/ in lib/ folder
5. Types: All calendar types are used extensively in API routes
6. Components: Only basic HTML elements used in page.tsx, no UI components imported

Cleanup findings completed - 6 agents analyzed calendar-aggregator project in parallel. Key findings: 214KB junk files (tsconfig.tsbuildinfo, memories.json), 4 unused npm packages (react-hook-form, zod, date-fns, @hookform/resolvers), entire UI components directory unused, duplicate API patterns across routes

memories.context: Dependency cleanup validation requested by user

memories.content:
Analyzed duplicate code patterns in calendar-aggregator API routes:

1. **Global Storage Initialization**: Pattern repeated across multiple files:
   - `/api/collections/route.ts` (lines 21-25)
   - `/api/collections/[guid]/route.ts` (lines 13-17)  
   - `/api/calendar/[guid]/route.ts` (lines 14-18)
   - `/api/calendars/route.ts` (lines 16-18, 36-41)

2. **GUID Validation**: UUID regex pattern duplicated:
   - `/api/calendar/[guid]/route.ts` (lines 81-83, 217-219)
   - Same validation logic used in both GET and HEAD methods

3. **findCollectionByGuid Function**: Identical implementations:
   - `/api/collections/[guid]/route.ts` (lines 107-139)
   - `/api/calendar/[guid]/route.ts` (lines 23-56)

4. **Error Handling Patterns**: Similar try-catch structures across all API routes:
   - Standard 400/404/500 responses with similar message formats
   - Generic error responses without specific context

5. **Supabase Fallback Logic**: Repeated database-to-memory fallback pattern in multiple operations

File analysis results:
1. debug-request.json: Contains user's personal calendar data (Google, Outlook, PerfectGym), not referenced in code, accidentally committed in ff42c9e (Aug 1), should be removed and added to .gitignore
2. memories.json: Claude MCP memory storage file with project context/decisions, not referenced in code, accidentally committed in e4b7a82 (Jul 31), should be removed and added to .gitignore
3. tsconfig.tsbuildinfo: TypeScript incremental build cache file, automatically generated by TypeScript compiler ("incremental": true in tsconfig.json), already listed in .gitignore but still committed, safe to remove as it will regenerate
memories.context: Git history and usage pattern analysis complete

memories.content:
COMPREHENSIVE DEAD CODE ANALYSIS - CONFIRMED FINDINGS:

## UI Components - ALL COMPLETELY UNUSED:
- Button, Card, Dialog, Input, Select, Toast, Loading, ErrorBoundary: Zero imports in actual application code
- Only cross-reference: ErrorBoundary imports Button and Card internally
- Main app (page.tsx, layout.tsx) uses only basic HTML elements, no UI component imports
- All 8 UI components in src/components/ui/ are completely dead code

## Hooks - COMPLETELY UNUSED:
- useDebounce: Zero imports/usage across entire codebase
- useLocalStorage: Zero imports/usage across entire codebase
- Both hooks exported but never consumed

## Utility Functions - MIXED USAGE:
- cn(): Used extensively by UI components (but since UI components unused, effectively dead)
- formatDate(), sleep(), capitalize(): ONLY used in test files, zero production usage
- Only cn() has any potential value if UI components were used

## Empty Directories - CONFIRMED EMPTY:
- src/lib/repositories/: Completely empty directory
- src/lib/services/: Completely empty directory

## Safe to Remove:
1. All 8 UI components in src/components/ui/
2. Both hooks in src/hooks/
3. formatDate, sleep, capitalize functions from utils.ts (keep cn for potential future use)
4. Empty repositories/ and services/ directories
memories.context: Dead code verification complete with evidence

Starting rapid cleanup protocol for calendar-aggregator project. No specific arguments provided, so executing comprehensive cleanup analysis. Project appears to be Next.js TypeScript app based on previous memory. Need to identify all cleanup opportunities with parallel agent processing for maximum speed.

Code duplication patterns found in calendar-aggregator project:

1. HTTP Client Duplication:
- calendar-utils.ts:64-71 and calendar-fetcher.ts:150-157 both have identical axios configurations with same timeout, User-Agent 'Calendar-Aggregator/1.0', maxRedirects: 5
- Both files handle axios errors with similar patterns (ECONNABORTED, ENOTFOUND, ECONNREFUSED)

2. Global Storage Management:
- Three files have identical initializeStorage() functions: collections/route.ts:21-25, collections/[guid]/route.ts:13-17, calendar/[guid]/route.ts:14-18
- All three have identical global variable declarations: declare global { var calendarCollections: CalendarCollection[] }

3. Database Operations:
- collections/route.ts and collections/[guid]/route.ts both have similar findCollectionByGuid functions with identical Supabase operations and fallback logic
- Similar error handling patterns for Supabase operations across multiple files

4. API Response Patterns:
- Multiple files have similar error response structures using NextResponse.json with status codes
- Similar validation error handling patterns across route files

Successfully completed code deduplication tasks for calendar-aggregator project:

COMPLETED TASKS:
1. ✅ Task 2: Extract global storage management into shared module
   - Added storage utilities to src/lib/utils.ts: initializeStorage, getStorageCollections, addCollectionToStorage, removeCollectionFromStorage, findCollectionInStorage, updateCollectionInStorage
   - Updated all API routes to use shared storage functions
   - Removed duplicate initializeStorage functions from 3 files

2. ✅ Task 3: Create API response utilities for standardized error handling  
   - Added ApiError and ApiSuccess interfaces to src/lib/utils.ts
   - Created helper functions: createErrorResponse, createSuccessResponse, createValidationErrorResponse, createNotFoundResponse, createServerErrorResponse
   - Standardized error handling patterns across API routes

3. ✅ Task 4: Consolidate Supabase operations with shared database utilities
   - Added shared database functions to src/lib/supabase.ts: saveCollectionToDatabase, getAllCollectionsFromDatabase, findCollectionByGuidInDatabase, updateCollectionInDatabase, deleteCollectionFromDatabase
   - Updated collections/route.ts, collections/[guid]/route.ts, and calendar/[guid]/route.ts to use shared functions
   - Removed duplicate Supabase operation code from multiple files

RESULTS:
- Build passes successfully ✅
- All tests pass (6/6) ✅
- Eliminated duplicate code patterns across 3 main areas
- Improved maintainability and consistency

PENDING: Task 1 (HTTP client utility) - deferred due to security hook false positive

Key benefits: Reduced code duplication, improved maintainability, standardized patterns, centralized error handling

Integration test creation completed successfully! Created comprehensive test file at src/__tests__/integration/collections.test.ts with 12 test cases covering:

- Calendar collection creation and retrieval
- GUID-based collection access  
- URL validation with smart mocking (valid for http/https/webcal URLs, invalid for malformed URLs)
- Input validation and error handling
- Webcal URL normalization
- Sequential ID assignment
- Default field values
- Empty collection handling
- Malformed JSON error handling
- Missing content-type header handling

Key fixes implemented:
1. Mocked validateCalendarUrl to avoid network calls in test environment
2. Fixed getAllCollectionsFromDatabase to fall back to global storage when Supabase unavailable

4. Proper global storage initialization in test setup

All 12 tests now pass successfully. The fallback to in-memory storage works correctly when Supabase environment variables are not set (expected in test environment).

Starting safe implementation of database-implementation tag. Need to research existing codebase patterns for calendar collections, understand current in-memory storage system, and plan migration to Supabase database schema.

memories.content:
Task 1 analysis: Database schema already exists and is working! Collections are being successfully saved and retrieved from Supabase. Current schema has basic structure (guid, name, description, sources JSONB, created_at, updated_at) with basic indexes and RLS. 

Task 1 requirement asks for enhanced schema with:
- UUID primary key with gen_random_uuid() (currently just TEXT guid) 
- Better indexes (including GIN on JSONB)
- More sophisticated RLS policies
- Update triggers
- Validation functions

Need to compare current vs required schema and apply improvements.

Ready to apply migration to database.

memories.content:
Successfully completed database-implementation tag for calendar-aggregator project. All tasks completed:

1. Database schema verification - Found existing functional schema
2. Service layer enhancement - Created comprehensive error handling and validation utilities
3. Database integration testing - All 27 tests passing with robust CRUD operations

Key achievements:
- Enhanced API routes with structured error handling
- Custom error classes (CalendarCollectionError, ValidationError, etc.)
- Comprehensive validation pipeline with sanitization
- Graceful fallback to in-memory storage when database unavailable
- Full test coverage including edge cases and error conditions
- Successful build verification with no TypeScript/ESLint errors

Files created/enhanced:
- src/lib/errors.ts - Custom error classes
- src/lib/validation.ts - Input validation and sanitization
- Enhanced API routes in src/app/api/collections/
- src/__tests__/integration/collections-crud.test.ts - New CRUD test suite
- DATABASE_INTEGRATION_TEST_RESULTS.md - Complete testing documentation

System now production-ready with enterprise-grade error handling and database integration.
memories.context: Database implementation safe-implementation task completion

memories.content: User wants to add custom ID feature for calendar collections. Key decisions: optional customId field in POST request, return 409 Conflict for duplicates, no migration needed for existing UUIDs, basic validation rules, URL-safe IDs only
memories.context: Planning custom ID feature for calendar aggregator

memories.content: Custom IDs Feature Implementation: Allow users to specify optional custom IDs when creating calendar collections, instead of only using automatically generated UUIDs. Tasks: 1) Add customId to interface 2) Modify POST handler 3) Update database layer 4) Add tests. Current system uses guid field with UUID generation.

Custom ID validation implementation completed: Added validateCustomId function with URL-safe format (3-50 chars, alphanumeric + hyphens/underscores, no leading/trailing special chars, reserved words blocked). Updated CreateCollectionRequest interface and validateCreateCollectionRequest function. Build passes.

Database layer case-insensitive uniqueness implemented: Modified findCollectionByGuidInDatabase to use ilike for custom IDs and exact match for UUIDs. Updated all in-memory storage functions (find, update, remove) to support case-insensitive lookup for custom IDs while maintaining UUID compatibility. Build passes.

Custom IDs Feature Implementation COMPLETE: 
✅ Added customId field to CreateCollectionRequest interface
✅ Implemented validateCustomId and validateId functions (URL-safe format, 3-50 chars, reserved words blocked)
✅ Updated POST /api/collections to handle customId with collision detection (409 response)
✅ Updated database layer for case-insensitive uniqueness (both Supabase and in-memory)  
✅ Updated all API routes to accept both UUIDs and custom IDs
✅ Created comprehensive test suite (14 tests all passing)
✅ Build verification successful
Feature allows users to create collections with memorable IDs like "my-work-calendar" instead of UUIDs.

Starting comprehensive codebase cleanup for calendar-aggregator project. Scope: full project cleanup with focus on safe removal of junk files, unused dependencies, dead code, and organizational improvements. User requested clean command with no specific arguments so applying full cleanup protocol.

memories.content: Starting comprehensive cleanup analysis for calendar-aggregator project. Target: full codebase cleanup with evidence-based approach. Safety-first protocol with parallel agent analysis.
memories.context: Initial cleanup scope analysis

memories.content:
Git History Staleness Analysis for Calendar Aggregator project:

KEY FINDINGS:
- Project is very recent (started July 31, 2025, most commits from August 2025)
- No files are actually stale (6+ months old) - project is less than 1 month old
- Most "stale" files are actually auto-generated Task Master command templates

PROJECT AGE: ~24 days old (created July 31, 2025)
- All commits from July 31 - August 24, 2025
- Active development with 30+ recent commits
- No files qualify as "6+ months stale" since project is brand new

ANALYSIS CATEGORIES:

1. AUTO-GENERATED TASK MASTER FILES (~75 files):
   - .claude/commands/tm/ hierarchy - Task Master command templates
   - .claude/agents/ - Claude agent definitions
   - These are framework files, not project-specific code

2. LEGACY CURSOR IDE CONFIG:
   - .cursor/mcp.json - Old Cursor IDE MCP configuration
   - Contains placeholder API keys, likely obsolete

3. BUILD ARTIFACTS:
   - .next/ directory contents (should be in .gitignore)
   - All build outputs are current from recent builds

4. POTENTIAL MAINTENANCE FILES:
   - openapi.yaml - Large API documentation (700+ lines)
   - Multiple schema*.sql files with recent updates
   - builder.config.json - Simple Vercel config

RECOMMENDATIONS:
- .cursor/mcp.json: PROBABLY_OBSOLETE (Cursor IDE specific)
- Task Master files: KEEP_FOR_REFERENCE (framework functionality)
- Build artifacts: Should be in .gitignore
- OpenAPI spec: KEEP (comprehensive documentation)
- Schema files: KEEP (active database definitions)

NO TRUE STALE FILES FOUND - Project too recent for 6+ month staleness analysis.

Agent analysis complete. Key findings: 1) Very clean codebase with minimal junk (~130K total cleanup), 2) Only 1 potentially unused dependency (critters), 3) Significant dead code in validation/error utilities (~400+ lines), 4) Project too new for staleness analysis, 5) Build system well-configured, 6) Zero test pollution but missing unit test coverage
memories.context: Comprehensive cleanup analysis results

memories.content: Created comprehensive backup and rollback strategy for calendar-aggregator cleanup with 5 executable scripts: cleanup-verification.sh (tests build/lint/test/API), emergency-rollback.sh (full git restoration), selective-restore.sh (individual file restoration), dependency-rollback.sh (package.json restoration), bundle-analysis.sh (size measurements). Strategy includes 3-phase incremental cleanup: Phase 1 (file artifacts), Phase 2 (unused dependencies), Phase 3 (dead code). All scripts executable and pre-cleanup metrics captured.

Build Dependencies Safety Verification - Calendar Aggregator Project

DEAD CODE ANALYSIS FINDINGS:

## Validation Functions (ACTUALLY USED)
- validateId() - USED in API routes [guid]/route.ts (calendar and collections) 
- validateCustomId() - USED in tests and called by validateId()
- validateCreateCollectionRequest() - USED in collections/route.ts POST
- validateGuid() - USED internally by validateCalendarCollection()
- Other validation functions - Used as internal dependencies

## Error Classes (ACTUALLY USED)
- ValidationError - USED throughout validation.ts (40+ instances)
- CollectionNotFoundError - USED in collections/[guid]/route.ts
- isCalendarCollectionError() - USED in API routes for error handling
- toCalendarCollectionError() - USED in API routes for error conversion
- Other error classes - Used as base classes or utilities

## Response Helpers (UNUSED - SAFE TO REMOVE)
- createValidationErrorResponse() - NOT USED (only defined)
- createNotFoundResponse() - NOT USED (only defined)  
- createServerErrorResponse() - NOT USED (only defined)

## Sanitization Functions (ACTUALLY USED)
- sanitizeCollectionName() - USED in collections/route.ts
- sanitizeCollectionDescription() - USED in collections/route.ts

VERIFICATION COMPLETE: Build successful, TypeScript compilation clean (no unused warnings), comprehensive grep searches show actual usage patterns.

Comprehensive backup and rollback strategy completed for calendar-aggregator cleanup. Created 8 executable scripts and 3 documentation files: verification script handles existing TypeScript errors gracefully, 3-phase incremental cleanup approach (artifacts → dependencies → code), multiple rollback layers (emergency, selective, git, dependencies), baseline measurement system, and complete safety net with success metrics. All scripts tested and ready for execution.

Safety verification complete. Correction: Most "dead code" is actually USED in APIs and tests. Only safe to remove: 3 response helper functions from utils.ts (lines 137-153). Complete backup & rollback strategy created with 8 scripts. Ready to proceed with minimal risk cleanup.
